## TL;DR  
In France you **don’t have a statutory “price‑setting” right** for an e‑book.  The price that appears on the retailer’s site is normally decided by the **publisher** (or the retailer, if the contract gives them that power).  

What you **can** negotiate – and what will ultimately determine how much money you earn – are the **economic‑rights clauses** of your publishing contract:

| What you can negotiate | Typical range / benchmark in France (2023‑2024) | Why it matters |
|------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|----------------|
| **Royalty rate** (percentage of the *net* sales price) | **10 % – 15 %** of net receipts for most small‑to‑mid‑size e‑book publishers; **15 % – 25 %** for very small or “self‑publishing‑assisted” platforms; **up to 30 %** for highly‑leveraged authors or when you retain marketing duties. | This is the main lever that translates the final retail price into your income. |
| **Advance on royalties** | Usually **€0 – €2 000** for a first‑time author with a modest catalogue; can be higher if you bring a proven audience or a strong marketing plan. | Paid up‑front; recouped against future royalties. |
| **Price‑floor clause** (minimum retail price) | Rare, but you can ask for a clause that the publisher may **not sell the e‑book below €X** (often €2.99‑€4.99 for a 100‑page work). | Gives you a safety net against “price‑war” discounting. |
| **Revenue‑share on discounts** | If the retailer discounts, you can request that the royalty be calculated on the **pre‑discount price** (or that the discount be limited to a set %). | Prevents your royalty from being eroded by deep discount campaigns. |
| **Territorial scope** | Usually **World‑wide** for digital rights; you can carve out **France‑only** or **EU‑only** to keep other territories for yourself. | Allows you to license the work elsewhere (e.g., to a print‑only house) and earn additional income. |
| **Term & re‑version** | 3‑5 years is standard; you can ask for **re‑version of rights** if sales fall below a threshold (e.g., < 500 copies sold per year). | Lets you regain control if the book under‑performs. |
| **Audit / accounting rights** | Right to request a **sales audit** (usually every 12 months) and to receive **detailed statements**. | Ensures you actually receive the royalties you’re owed. |
| **Marketing & promotion budget** | You can ask for a **fixed marketing budget** (e.g., €500‑€1 000) or a **percentage of sales** earmarked for promotion. | Improves visibility → higher sales → higher royalties. |
| **Moral‑rights clause** | French law gives you **inalienable moral rights** (right of attribution, right of integrity, right to respect of the work). You can require the publisher to **respect the integrity of your annotations** and to **display your name prominently**. | Protects the artistic integrity of your collection. |

Below is a step‑by‑step guide that explains **why you have these levers, what the law says, and how to use them in practice**.

---

## 1. The Legal Landscape in France

### 1.1. No “price‑setting” right for e‑books  
* **Printed books** in France are subject to the *“prix unique du livre”* (fixed‑price law, **Article L. 311‑1 of the Code du Livre**). This law obliges the publisher to set a single retail price that all retailers must respect.  
* **E‑books** are **not** covered by the fixed‑price law (the European Commission has repeatedly confirmed that the digital book market is exempt). Consequently, the **publisher (or the retailer, if the contract delegates that power) can set the final retail price** and can run discount campaigns at will.

> **Bottom line:** You cannot demand a statutory price ceiling or floor for your e‑book. The only way to influence the price is through contractual clauses (price‑floor, royalty‑on‑pre‑discount price, etc.).

### 1.2. Moral rights (droits moraux) – non‑negotiable but enforceable  
French copyright law (Code de la propriété intellectuelle, **Articles L. 121‑1 à L. 121‑8**) grants authors **inalienable moral rights**:

| Moral right | What it means for you |
|-------------|----------------------|
| **Right of attribution** (droit de paternité) | Your name must appear on every edition, in a form you approve. |
| **Right of respect for the work** (droit au respect de l’œuvre) | The publisher may not modify, mutilate, or distort your text without your consent. |
| **Right of disclosure** (droit de divulgation) | You decide when and how the work is first made public (relevant if you have already posted parts online). |
| **Right of withdrawal** (droit de retrait) | You may request the work be withdrawn under certain conditions (rarely exercised). |

These rights **cannot be waived** (they are perpetual, inalienable, and imprescriptible). In a contract you can **explicitly require the publisher to respect them**, but you cannot sell them away.

### 1.3. Economic rights (droits patrimoniaux) – fully negotiable  
The **economic rights** (right to reproduce, distribute, make available to the public, etc.) are **exploitable by contract**. The publisher will ask for an **exclusive licence** (or sometimes a **full transfer**) for the e‑book format. You can:

* Grant **exclusive** rights for a limited term and territory.
* Keep **non‑exclusive** rights for other formats (print, audio, translation, etc.).
* Reserve **secondary licences** (e.g., for educational platforms, libraries, or subscription services).

These are the clauses that determine **how much you get paid**.

---

## 2. What “Price” Means in a Publishing Contract

When you see a royalty expressed as a **percentage of the “sale price”**, French contracts usually distinguish between:

| Term | Definition | Typical base for royalty calculation |
|------|------------|--------------------------------------|
| **Prix de vente public (PVP)** | The *retail* price shown to the consumer (incl. VAT). | Rarely used for royalties because retailers discount heavily. |
| **Prix net éditeur (PNE)** | The *net* amount the publisher receives from the retailer after discounts, VAT, and retailer margin. | Most common basis for royalty calculations. |
| **Prix de gros** | The price the publisher sells the e‑book to a reseller (e.g., Amazon, Kobo). | Used when the publisher sells the rights to a platform that then sets its own price. |

**Negotiation tip:** Ask for the royalty to be calculated on the **PNE** *before* any retailer discount, or set a **minimum PNE** (e.g., “royalty = 12 % of the net price, but not less than €0.30 per copy”).

---

## 3. Typical Royalty Structures for French E‑books

| Publisher type | Royalty % of Net Receipts | Advance (if any) | Comments |
|----------------|--------------------------|------------------|----------|
| **Large house (e.g., Gallimard, Le Livre de Poche)** | 8 % – 12 % | €2 000 – €5 000 (rare for debut) | Usually *exclusif* worldwide; price set by publisher; strong distribution. |
| **Mid‑size independent (e.g., Actes Sud, Le Seuil)** | 10 % – 15 % | €0 – €2 000 | May allow price‑floor clause; often more flexible on rights. |
| **Small niche / “self‑publishing‑assisted” platform (e.g., Bookelis, Publishroom)** | 15 % – 25 % | Usually **no advance** | You may retain marketing duties; higher royalty compensates for lower upfront cash. |
| **Pure‑play e‑book aggregator (e.g., Kobo Writing Life, Amazon KDP)** | 30 % – 70 % of the *list price* (because they are the retailer) | No advance | You set the list price yourself; you keep the whole royalty after the platform’s cut. |

> **If your French editor is an *online‑only* publisher that distributes through third‑party retailers (Kobo, Apple Books, etc.), the most common model is **royalty on net receipts** (10‑15 %).**  

---

## 4. Negotiation Levers – How to Build Your “Margin”

Below is a **practical checklist** you can use when you sit down (or Zoom) with the editor. For each item, I note the **legal basis**, **typical range**, and **sample clause** you can propose.

| # | Issue | Legal basis / market practice | What to ask for | Sample clause |
|---|-------|------------------------------|----------------|---------------|
| 1 | **Royalty rate** | No statutory minimum; market‑driven. | 12 % – 15 % of net receipts (or 20 % if you handle your own marketing). | “L’Éditeur versera à l’Auteur une redevance de 13 % du prix net perçu pour chaque exemplaire vendu.” |
| 2 | **Advance** | Optional; recouped from royalties. | €1 000 – €2 000 (or waive for higher royalty). | “Un acompte de €1 500 sera versé à la signature, déductible des redevances futures.” |
| 3 | **Price‑floor** | Not required by law, but enforceable contractually. | Minimum retail price €3.99 (or €0.30 per copy net). | “Le Prix de Vente Public ne pourra être inférieur à €3,99, sauf accord écrit préalable de l’Auteur.” |
| 4 | **Discount‑royalty clause** | Protects royalty from deep discounts. | Royalty calculated on *pre‑discount* net price; discount limited to 20 % of list price. | “En cas de remise appliquée par le détaillant, la redevance sera calculée sur le prix net avant remise, la remise ne pouvant excéder 20 % du prix de liste.” |
| 5 | **Territorial scope** | You can limit the licence. | France‑only for e‑book; you retain rights for other territories. | “La licence est exclusive pour le territoire de la France métropolitaine et de la DROM‑COM. L’Auteur se réserve le droit d’exploiter le titre hors de ce périmètre.” |
| 6 | **Term & re‑version** | Standard 3‑5 years; re‑version clause is common. | 3 years, renouvelable automatically if sales > 500 copies/yr; otherwise rights revert. | “Le présent contrat est conclu pour une durée de trois (3) ans. Au terme, les droits reviendront à l’Auteur si les ventes annuelles sont inférieures à 500 exemplaires.” |
| 7 | **Audit rights** | Article L. 132‑1‑1 du Code de la propriété intellectuelle (right to accounts). | Annual audit, cost‑share if discrepancy < 5 %. | “L’Auteur pourra, à ses frais, faire auditer les comptes de l’Éditeur une fois par an. Si l’audit révèle un écart supérieur à 5 % des redevances dues, les frais d’audit seront à la charge de l’Éditeur.” |
| 8 | **Marketing budget** | Not mandated, but negotiable. | €500‑€1 000 earmarked for online ads + social‑media push. | “L’Éditeur s’engage à consacrer un budget minimum de €800 à la promotion du titre pendant les six (6) premiers mois suivant la mise en ligne.” |
| 9 | **Moral‑rights protection** | Inalienable (Code de la propriété intellectuelle). | Explicit clause that annotations cannot be altered without your written consent. | “L’Éditeur s’engage à ne pas modifier, raccourcir ou réarranger les annotations de l’Auteur sans son accord écrit préalable.” |
|10| **Rights for excerpts** | You must have clearance for the newspaper extracts. | Publisher to verify you have secured all necessary permissions; otherwise you indemnify. | “L’Auteur garantit qu’il détient toutes les autorisations nécessaires pour les extraits de presse incorporés. L’Éditeur est dégagé de toute responsabilité en cas de réclamation, sous réserve de la bonne foi de l’Auteur.” |

---

## 5. The “Excerpt” Issue – Do You Need Additional Permissions?

Your book is **a collection of newspaper extracts that you have annotated and regrouped**. French copyright law treats **quotations** as a *fair‑use‑like* exception (**Article L. 122‑5, 3°**), **provided**:

1. The excerpt is **short** relative to the whole work.
2. The source is **clearly identified** (newspaper name, date, author).
3. The quotation is **justified by the purpose** (critique, analysis, illustration).

**However**, the “shortness” test is **subjective**. For a compilation that may contain dozens of multi‑paragraph extracts, a publisher will usually ask you to **obtain the rights** from the original press owners (or rely on a blanket licence from *Société des éditeurs de presse* if one exists).  

**What to do:**

| Step | Action | Why |
|------|--------|-----|
| 1 | **Make an inventory** of every excerpt (title, date, author, length). | Needed for clearance. |
| 2 | **Check if the newspaper belongs to a collective rights organisation** (e.g., *Syndicat de la presse quotidienne régionale*). | May allow a single licence fee. |
| 3 | **Contact the rights holder** (usually the newspaper’s publishing house) for a **licence** (often a flat fee per excerpt or a per‑copy royalty). | Avoids infringement claims. |
| 4 | **Document the licences** and attach them as annexes to the publishing contract. | Gives the publisher proof of clearance. |
| 5 | **If you cannot obtain clearance**, consider **rewriting the excerpts** as *paraphrases* and limit direct quotations to a few lines. | Reduces legal risk, but you must still credit the source. |

> **Bottom line:** The publisher will **not** take on the risk of copyright infringement for the newspaper extracts. You must **clear them yourself** (or prove they fall under the quotation exception). Failure to do so can lead to the contract being voided or you being liable for damages.

---

## 6. Sample “Negotiation Script” (How to Phrase Your Requests)

> **You:** “Thank you for the offer. I’m excited about publishing the collection. Before we sign, I’d like to discuss a few points that are important for me as the author.”
> 
> **1. Royalty & Advance**  
> “Given the niche nature of the work and the fact that I will be handling most of the promotional activities, I propose a royalty of **13 % of net receipts** and an **advance of €1 500**. This aligns with market rates for similar titles from independent e‑book publishers.”
> 
> **2. Price‑floor**  
> “To protect the perceived value of the work, could we set a **minimum retail price of €3,99**? This is a common clause for digital titles that rely on a limited‑edition positioning.”
> 
> **3. Discount‑royalty**  
> “If the retailer applies a discount, I’d like the royalty to be calculated on the **pre‑discount net price**, with any discount limited to **20 %** of the list price. This ensures my earnings are not eroded by deep discount campaigns.”
> 
> **4. Rights & Territory**  
> “I would like the licence to be **exclusive for France only** for the e‑book format, with the possibility to negotiate print or translation rights separately.”
> 
> **5. Term & Re‑version**  
> “A three‑year term with an automatic renewal clause tied to a minimum of **500 copies sold per year** sounds fair. If sales fall below that, the rights revert to me.”
> 
> **6. Audit**  
> “I request an **annual audit right** with a cost‑share arrangement (you cover the audit if the discrepancy exceeds 5 %).”
> 
> **7. Marketing**  
> “Could we allocate a **€800 marketing budget** for the first six months, focused on targeted social‑media ads and placement on French e‑book platforms?”
>
